title: Broadway Sees Box Office Magic In Comedians, Rock Stars and Illusionists
text:
The next big thing on Broadway may not be a musical or play.

Concert stars, comedians and other nontheatrical artists are finding their way to the Great White Way. And audiences are coming to their shows in respectable numbers.

Among the latest productions in this vein are “ Derren Brown : Secret” and “Freestyle Love Supreme.”

The former brings the British mind-reader and illusionist, who has played sold-out runs in London’s West End, to Broadway for the first time. The latter is a show that blends hip-hop and improvisation and was created by “Hamilton” composer Lin-Manuel Miranda in collaboration with Thomas Kail and Anthony Veneziale.

“Derren Brown: Secret” opened Sunday to positive reviews. The show is also off to a solid start at the box office, according to figures from the Broadway League, an industry trade group. It drew an audience of 94% capacity during the past week’s run of seven shows, which included six preview performances. (Attendance did, however, include several members of the press as is typical during the preview period.)

“Freestyle Love Supreme” started playing previews this past week. Over four preview performances, it played to an audience of 89% capacity.

Other nontheatrical shows have had notable runs on Broadway in the past year. Most notably, a series of presentations at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre, including those by such high-profile acts as Barry Manilow and Dave Chappelle, did fairly well. In particular, Mr. Chappelle played a nearly sold-out run of 10 shows.

Michael Rego, a partner in the Araca Group, one of the producers behind the Lunt-Fontanne series, said it “far exceeded our expectations.” He added that he hopes to bring more nontheatrical presentations to Broadway.

“Our model is something we’re going to keep utilizing for years to come,” he said.

In many ways, the precedent for this approach is Bruce Springsteen ’s massively successful 14-month stint on Broadway, which ended in December 2018. His show, which was something of a concert-play hybrid, sold out every performance and grossed $113 million for the run.

‘Derren Brown: Secret’ opened Sunday to positive reviews. Photo: Matthew Murphy

In turn, this has garnered interest in Broadway from other performers, said Jordan Roth, president of Jujamcyn Theaters, one of the prominent theater chains on Broadway.

Mr. Springsteen “got many extraordinary artists thinking this is a canvas to take seriously,” said Mr. Roth. Mr. Springsteen’s show was presented at the Walter Kerr Theatre, a Jujamcyn venue.

Some nontheatrical shows have already been announced for the months ahead. Among them is a return of “The Illusionists,” a magic-themed show that has become a fixture on Broadway during the winter holiday season.

Also on tap: Veteran jazz and popular musician Harry Connick, Jr. , will present a tribute to Cole Porter, with previews slated to begin in December.
